chapter.title: Scope
chapter.para: This document defines how WebRTC and related protocols are to be used for ONVIF clients and devices to establish a peer-to-peer connection between a client and a device using a signaling server.

chapter.title: Overview
chapter.para: The WebRTC standard includes APIs for communicating with an ICE Server, but the signaling component is not part of it. Signaling is needed in order for two peers to share how they should connect.
Signaling can be implemented in many different ways, and the WebRTC standard doesn't prefer any specific solution.

This specification contains documentation and examples of the signaling protocol used in ONVIF to set up a WebRTC peer-to-peer connection. The setup involves three participants: client, device and signaling server.

In this figure,
The client represents a real user who initiates the WebRTC session.
The device is the resource delivering the media, for example a camera.
The signaling server is the mediator that both client and device connect to in order to establish a peer-to-peer connection between them.
The Signaling Protocol described in this specification details the data exchange between client and device via the signaling server. The formal API is defined in a separate AsyncAPI schema file.
Once a peer-to-peer connection has been established, how WebRTC is used is described in the WebRTC usage chapter.

chapter.title: Signaling Protocol
chapter.para: The Signaling Protocol defines the messages between a client and a device in a WebRTC system with the intension of esatblishing a peer-to-peer connection between the client and a device. The messages are always sent via the signaling server called server from now on. Once a peer-to-peer connection has been established the connection with the server can be dropped without affecting the peer-to-peer connection. It's however recommended to keep the server connection open to be able receive error messages from the server.

Since the headers of the messages differ depending on whether the message is sent between client and server, or between device and server, we specify two separate versions of the interface. One between client and server, called client-facing from now on, and one between device and server, called device-facing from now on.

section.title: Connecting to the signaling server
section.para: Both a client and a device need to connect to the server by setting up a WebSocket with valid access tokens that the server will accept. The connection handling is done using WebSocket [RFC 6455].
The signaling messages are then sent as JSON text messages in the WebSocket. Please refer to the Signaling Protocol AsyncAPI schema for specific details regarding the Signaling Protocol.

section.title: Client
section.para: A client connects to the server by setting up a WebSocket to, for example: wss://signaling.example.com/client?authorization=Bearer%20access_token

Where signaling.example.com should be replaced with the server's address, and access_token should be replaced with a valid access token that the server will accept. See section for how to get an access token.
The WebSocket sub protocol shall be set to 'client.webrtc.onvif.org' for the client.

section.para: A device must first be onboarded in order to be able to set up a WebSocket to the server. See section for more information. An onboarded device then connects by setting up a WebSocket to, for example:

A signed JWT also needs to be provided (token). This must be signed using the device's private key that correspond to the device's public key that was used when onboarding. See section
The WebSocket sub protocol shall be set to 'device.webrtc.onvif.org' for the device.

section.title: hello
section.para: Directly after connecting a WebSocket to the server the client or device gets a hello message from the server, with the peer's assigned Signaling ID.

section.title: Message structure
section.para: Generally a message contains two parts: header and payload. The header part is processed by the server and the payload part is intended for the peer (device or client).

Since message header content differs depending on whether the message is client- or device-facing, the header keys are grouped accordingly while the payload keys are not. The payload keys remain the same, regardless of peer.
NOTE: Messages sent via the server may be delivered out-of-order; for optimal scalability messages should be handled asynchronously.
Below are explanations of key/value pairs that are used in the protocol.

section.title: General header keys
section.para: The following key/value pairs are used in the header of both client- and device-facing messages.

section.title: Client-facing header keys
section.para: The following key/value pairs are used in the header part in client messages.

entry.para: The Signaling ID of the device to which the message is intended, or the device that sent the message. This ID is unique within the organization. See section for how to get available IDs.
The ID of the organization that the device belongs to. This ID is unique within the signaling server. See section for how to get available IDs.

Access token for the logged in user. This should be in JWT format according to [RFC 7519]. See section for how to get an access token. The token is checked by the peer for every command. If it has expiried it sends an unauthorized error and the client must retry with an updated token.
An optional identifier chosen by the client that can be used to correlate the response from the signaling server with the request. Echoed back in the signaling server response.

section.title: Device-facing header keys
section.para: The following key/value pairs are used in the header part in device messages.

row.entry: The Signaling ID of the client to which the message is intended, or the client that sent the message. This ID is unique within the organization and the device gets this id from server during initSession.

section.title: Payload keys
section.para: The following key/value pairs are used in the payload part of messages.

entry.para: The API version that should be used in the request.

row.entry: Specifies whether this message is a request or response.
An identifier chosen by the client that should be used for all subsequent messages belonging to this session to and from the device.
Specifies which request method this message concerns.
An optional identifier chosen by the requestor that can be used to correlate the response from the receiver with the request. Echoed back in the response.

section.title: Param level keys inside params blocks
section.para: The following key/value pairs are used inside params blocks in the payload part of messages.

entry.para: Sub function of the method. Can be "offer" or "answer".
The media profile to use for this session. If none is specified the device will choose a default profile. See section for how to get available profiles.
An SDP record as described in RFC 8829.

section.title: Initialize a new WebRTC session
section.para: A new WebRTC session is initiated by the client requesting the device to produce an SDP offer using an initSession message.

section.title: initSession
section.para: An initSession message is sent from the client to the signaling server to request a new WebRTC session to a device. A message of type live should be used to request a live video and/or audio session.
The server responds to the client with a copy of the initSession message, including details for the STUN and TURN servers that can be used.
The server also sends a copy of the message, with updated headers, to the device.
The device acknowledges that it has received the initSession message.

section.title: Faults
section.para: The following errors can be set in the initSession messages: 1100, 1101, 2100, 2101, 2102, 2103, 2104, 2105, 2106, 2107, 2108, 2109, 2110. See section for more details on errors.

section.title: SDP record exchange
section.para: Once a P2P signaling channel has been set up using the initSession message the next step is to exchange SDP records. The dynamics and the format of the SDP records are defined in RFC 8829.

section.title: setSdpOffer
section.para: A setSdpOffer message is always sent from the device, via server, to the client.

The client MAY acknowledge the received SDP offer with a response after validating the message. Although this is not strictly necessary it can be helpful to send these acknowledgements to ease debugging the signaling flow.

section.title: setSdpAnswer
section.para: A setSdpAnswer message is always sent from the client, via server, to the device.
A device MUST send a response back to the client (via server) after validating the message. This message indicates that the device has successfully validated the setSdpAnswer request.

section.title: Faults
section.para: The following errors can be set in the responses to the setSdpOffer or setSdpAnswer messages: 1100, 1101, 2100, 2101, 2102, 2103, 2104, 2105, 2106, 2107, 2108, 2109, 2110. See section for more details on errors.

section.title: ICE candidate exchange
section.para: Next step is to exchange ICE candidates. The format of the ICE candidate strings are defined in RFC 8829.

section.title: addIceCandidate
section.para: Both client and device produce ICE candidates and send them to each other, via the server, in any order, using an addIceCandidate message.
NOTE: Note that ICE candidates can arrive before the SDP offer and the implementing client needs to handle this.

If everything works as it should, a peer-to-peer WebRTC session can be set up between client and device. After the session has been established the client can terminate the WebSocket session to the signaling server and the peer-to-peer connection will not be affected. However, it's recommended to keep the WebSocket session to the server open to be able to receive event messages from the signaling server.

section.title: Faults
section.para: The following errors can be set in the response to the addIceCandidate message: 1100, 1101, 2100, 2101, 2102, 2103, 2104, 2105, 2106, 2107, 2108, 2109, 2110. See section for more details on errors.

section.title: Error handling
section.para: Errors that can be immediately reported when receiving a request are reported directly in its corresponding response. However, errors may also occur later during the subsequent session setup or after it has been setup and is running. These types of errors are reported in an event message. Both 'events' and 'responses' include a numeric error code, and a human-readable message. When errors are reported by the client or device the error message is encapsulated in a signaling message. The server may itself send errors by using its own error type message.

section.title: Reconnecting
section.para: If the session is disconnected it's up to the client to reconnect again using the same procedure as was used initially, i.e. start from scratch. Each client should use an individual ascending interval strategy to avoid that all clients reconnect at the same time.

chapter.title: WebRTC Usage
chapter.para: This chapter describes ONVIF specific usage of WebRTC regarding how to send data between the client and device on the peer-to-peer connection.

Devices MAY define profiles for different streaming scenarios that can be choosen by the client based on the available bandwidth or other limiting factors. For example, a specific profile for mobile clients, another one for high quality streaming, etc.

section.title: Video
section.para: When using WebRTC with a web browser only certain codecs will work. Because of this ONVIF recommends to use the h.264 codec.
In line with WebRTC standard, ONVIF also recommends to always use congestion control to ensure that WebRTC cannot be used to flood the network.

section.title: Audio
section.para: When using WebRTC with a web browser only certain codecs will work. Because of this ONVIF recommends to use the Opus or PCMU codec.
For two-way audio it's recommended to use echo cancellation to avoid feedback loops.

section.title: Metadata
section.para: A device could send event and analytics metadata on a WebRTC datachannel. This is not covered in this version of this specifcation but may be added in future versions.

section.title: Commands
section.para: A client could send PTZ and other commands on a WebRTC datachannel. This is not covered in the this version of this specifcation but may be added in future versions.

chapter.title: Authentication Protocol
chapter.para: This section describes how users and devices autheticates and get access to services.

section.title: User login and access
section.para: A user logs in and gets an access token using OAuth2 and OpenID Connect. This is described in the [ONVIF Security Specification].

section.title: Device access
section.para: In order for a device to connect to a signaling server an Authorization Server Configuration must have been set up during device onboarding. See the [ONVIF Security Service] regarding Authorization Server Configurations. This configuration tells the device how to get an access token that can be used to connect to the signaling server.
